episodeTitle: The Three-Sword Style's Past! Zoro and Kuina's Vow!
description: Zoro naps and dreams of his childhood at the Isshin Dojo, where he trained under Koushirou and competed with the master's daughter, Kuina. Their rivalry and promise to become the world's greatest swordsman is revealed, along with the tragic circumstances that led Zoro to inherit the Wado Ichimonji. Meanwhile, Luffy fires cannons at rocks, angering Zoro's old bounty hunter friend Johnny, who mistakes them for enemies.

events.title: Johnny's First Appearance
events.description: Johnny, a bounty hunter and old friend of Zoro, attacks the Going Merry after Luffy accidentally fires a cannon at the rock where he and Yosaku were resting. Zoro recognizes Johnny, preventing a confrontation.
events.significance: Introduces Johnny, who will help guide the Straw Hats to the Baratie and later assist during the Arlong Park Arc.

events.title: Zoro's Flashback Begins
events.description: Zoro falls asleep and begins dreaming of his childhood at Shimotsuki Village, where he was known as a dojoyaburi (dojo challenger) who went from dojo to dojo seeking strong opponents to fight.
events.significance: This flashback episode provides crucial backstory explaining Zoro's motivation to become the world's greatest swordsman and the origin of his three-sword style.

events.title: Kuina's First Appearance
events.description: Young Kuina is introduced as the daughter of dojo master Koushirou and the strongest student at the Isshin Dojo. She defeats young Zoro in a sword match, marking her 2001st consecutive victory against him.
events.significance: Kuina is revealed as Zoro's greatest rival and childhood friend, establishing the foundation for his dream and motivation throughout the series.

quotes.text: That makes it 2001 wins for me!
quotes.speaker: Kuina
quotes.context: Kuina defeats Zoro for the two-thousandth and first time

events.title: Koushirou's First Appearance
events.description: Shimotsuki Koushirou is introduced as the master of the Isshin Dojo and Kuina's father. He oversees the training of young Zoro and other students at the dojo.
events.significance: Koushirou becomes Zoro's teacher and mentor, shaping his development as a swordsman and later entrusting him with the Wado Ichimonji.

events.title: Kuina Defeats Zoro in Real Sword Duel
events.description: In the middle of the night, Kuina accepts Zoro's challenge to fight with real swords instead of bamboo practice swords. Wielding the Wado Ichimonji, she defeats Zoro once again, but this time both fighters acknowledge each other's strength and determination.
events.significance: This duel with real swords represents the mutual respect between Zoro and Kuina, and showcases the Wado Ichimonji sword that will later become Zoro's most treasured blade.

events.title: Zoro and Kuina's Vow
events.description: After their midnight duel, Zoro and Kuina make a solemn promise to each other: one of them will become the world's greatest swordsman. They vow to train harder than anyone else to achieve this dream, establishing a pact that will define Zoro's entire life.
events.significance: This promise becomes the driving force behind Zoro's ambition and shapes his entire journey. It's one of the most important character-defining moments in the series, establishing Zoro's core motivation that persists throughout all of One Piece.

quotes.text: I promise! One of us will become the world's greatest swordsman!
quotes.speaker: Zoro and Kuina
quotes.context: The two rivals make their legendary vow to each other

events.title: Kuina's Death Revealed
events.description: The day after making their promise, Kuina tragically dies by falling down a staircase at the dojo. Her sudden and unexpected death devastates young Zoro and the entire dojo.
events.significance: Kuina's death is the catalyst that transforms Zoro's dream from a personal rivalry into a sacred mission. This tragedy shapes Zoro's entire character arc and explains his unwavering dedication to becoming the world's greatest swordsman.

events.title: Zoro Inherits the Wado Ichimonji
events.description: After Kuina's funeral, Zoro tearfully asks Koushirou for Kuina's sword, the Wado Ichimonji. Koushirou grants his request, entrusting the prized Meito blade to Zoro so he can fulfill their shared dream of becoming the world's greatest swordsman.
events.significance: The Wado Ichimonji becomes Zoro's most important sword, representing his promise to Kuina. Unlike his other swords which he later replaces, Zoro never parts with this blade throughout the entire series. This moment also marks the beginning of Zoro's three-sword style.

quotes.text: I'll become so strong that my name will be known even in heaven! I'll become the world's greatest swordsman!
quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Zoro's tearful vow after receiving the Wado Ichimonji

events.title: Origin of the Three-Sword Style
events.description: The flashback reveals why Zoro fights with three swords: he carries Kuina's sword (Wado Ichimonji) in addition to his own two swords, symbolically fighting with her strength as well as his own to fulfill their mutual promise.
events.significance: Explains the origin and meaning behind Zoro's unique three-sword fighting style, revealing it's not just a technique but a memorial to his fallen friend and their shared dream.

events.title: Journey Toward the Baratie
events.description: After Yosaku is revealed to be suffering from scurvy, Johnny offers to guide the Straw Hats to the Baratie, a floating restaurant where they can find a cook and get medicine. This sets up the next arc.
events.significance: This episode serves as the transition into the Baratie Arc, one of the most important arcs in the East Blue Saga where Sanji joins the crew.

quotes.text: I promise! One of us will become the world's greatest swordsman!
quotes.speaker: Zoro and Kuina
quotes.context: Zoro and Kuina's legendary vow to each other

quotes.text: I'll become so strong that my name will be known even in heaven! I'll become the world's greatest swordsman!
quotes.speaker: Roronoa Zoro
quotes.context: Zoro's tearful declaration after inheriting the Wado Ichimonji

quotes.text: That makes it 2001 wins for me!
quotes.speaker: Kuina
quotes.context: After defeating Zoro for the two-thousand and first consecutive time

themes.description: The episode explores how dreams can be inherited and carried forward. Zoro takes on not just his own dream but also Kuina's, vowing to become strong enough for both of them.
themes.symbolism: The Wado Ichimonji represents the weight of promises and inherited dreams, a physical manifestation of Zoro's vow to Kuina.
culturalReferences: Japanese sword culture and the honor associated with inheriting a master's blade

themes.description: Kuina expresses frustration that as a girl, she believes she will eventually be surpassed by Zoro simply due to physical differences, reflecting traditional gender attitudes in martial arts.
themes.symbolism: Kuina's struggle represents fighting against societal expectations and self-imposed limitations.
culturalReferences: Traditional Japanese views on women in martial arts

themes.description: Kuina's sudden death shows how fragile life can be, but also how one's dreams and will can live on through others. Her death motivates Zoro to carry both their dreams forward.
themes.symbolism: Zoro training with three swords symbolizes carrying Kuina's strength alongside his own.
culturalReferences: The concept of inherited will, a recurring theme in One Piece

themes.description: Zoro and Kuina's relationship shows how rivalry can coexist with deep friendship and mutual respect. Their competition pushed both to become stronger.
themes.symbolism: The 2001 defeats represent perseverance and the refusal to give up despite repeated failure.

characterSpotlights.development: This episode provides essential backstory for Zoro, revealing the origin of his dream, his three-sword style, and the emotional weight he carries. We see him transform from a stubborn child challenger into someone with a profound sense of duty and honor.
keyActions: Challenges Kuina repeatedly despite losing 2001 times
Makes a vow with Kuina to become the world's greatest swordsman
Asks for Kuina's sword after her death
Vows to become so strong his name reaches heaven
quotes: I promise! One of us will become the world's greatest swordsman!
I'll become so strong that my name will be known even in heaven! I'll become the world's greatest swordsman!

characterSpotlights.role: Zoro's rival and the emotional core of the episode
characterSpotlights.development: Kuina is introduced as a prodigy swordsman who struggles with societal expectations about gender. Despite her strength, she fears being limited by being female. Her death and the passing of her sword to Zoro creates the foundation for his character throughout the series.
keyActions: Accepts Zoro's challenge to duel with real swords
Makes a promise with Zoro to become the world's greatest swordsman
quotes: That makes it 2001 wins for me!
I promise! One of us will become the world's greatest swordsman!

characterSpotlights.development: Koushirou is introduced as a calm, wise sensei who recognizes Zoro's potential and determination. After his daughter's death, he entrusts Zoro with the Wado Ichimonji, showing his faith in Zoro to carry on Kuina's legacy.
keyActions: Oversees the training at Isshin Dojo
Allows Zoro to train at the dojo after defeating him
Gives Zoro the Wado Ichimonji after Kuina's death

characterSpotlights.development: Johnny debuts as an old friend of Zoro from his bounty hunting days, providing a connection to Zoro's past and serving as a guide to the Baratie.
keyActions: Attacks the Going Merry after Luffy hits their rock
Offers to guide the Straw Hats to the Baratie

mangaDifferences.difference: The flashback to Zoro's past is significantly expanded in the anime compared to the manga, with additional scenes of young Zoro's training and interactions with Kuina.
The anime adds the detail that Kuina was looking for a whetstone to sharpen the Wado Ichimonji when she fell down the stairs.
Johnny's introduction and the setup for the Baratie arc is expanded with more comedic moments involving Luffy firing cannons.

trivia.fact: This is the first major backstory episode in One Piece, establishing the pattern of flashback episodes that would become a hallmark of the series.

Kuina's death by falling down stairs is one of the most controversial deaths in One Piece, with many fans finding it anticlimactic for such a skilled fighter. This has led to numerous fan theories about the true circumstances of her death.
The Wado Ichimonji is classified as one of the 21 O Wazamono (Great Grade Swords) and is the only one of Zoro's original three swords that he still carries to this day.

Unshō Ishizuka, who voiced Koushirou in this episode, also voiced other notable One Piece characters including Borsalino (Kizaru). After his death in 2018, Kenji Nomura took over the role of Koushirou.
This episode adapts material from both Chapter 5 (from early in the manga) and Chapter 42 (much later), as Oda inserted this flashback during the Baratie Arc.
Episode 19 marks the beginning of the Baratie Arc, which runs from episodes 19-30 and introduces Sanji, who becomes the crew's cook.
The number 2001 (Kuina's victories over Zoro) is significant as it represents Zoro's incredible perseverance - he never gave up despite losing over two thousand times.
